Actually, you may have invented a great way to sear a steak without realizing it.

The key point is that using molten salt on a steak appears to thoroughly and quickly sear it.

Flavors could be added by marinating or dry brining the meat before searing with molten salt. The problem with relying on molten kosher salt for seasoning is that the meat sears too quickly for the salt to really flavor it.

After searing, then you'd cook the steak to your desired level doneness on a grill with indirect heat, perhaps basting it with olive oil or melted butter, perhaps even applying garlic, salt, and/or pepper to help the flavoring of the crust.

I'll bet the result is going to be a very juicy steak with a delectable crust, even if it's cooked well done (prefer medium rare myself), all because the searing was done so rapidly and thoroughly.

So, you might actually want to revisit this experiment by first seasoning the meat before cooking and then following up with indirect cooking on a charcoal or a gas grill after searing.

Who knows, you might even want to open a steakhouse that cooks meat this way.

You probably know this but for the few who may not, when you salt the steak, it first draws moisture out and then the steak reabsorbs the salty moisture.  That's what gives the steak its initial saltiness.  Molten salt definitely drew moisture out but did not have the opportunity to be absorbed into the meat.  Try cooking the steak on very hot but not molten salt.  It may give the steak enough time to cook through while forming a nice crust.  Some might also get absorbed but I doubt it would have enough time to salt the meat.  While you are at it, cook some veggies on the salt, too (like onions, zucchini, and maybe corn). Also, best and easiest seasoning for steak.
Simple. Be super gentle with some EVOO, pepper and salt generously. Massage minced fresh garlic into the steak. Let it it come to room temp before cooking (trust. If it's fresh steak, you've nothing to worry bout)
Get a cast iron pan screaming hot and your broiler going. Slap some butter in the pan, throw some more garlic in the pan with some rosemary, slap the steak in there. 3 mins. Flip it. 2 mins. Stick into oven for 5 mins under the broiler. (Times may vary by oven)
Take it out. Test cut. If it's to your liking, plate it. Let it rest COVERED for as long as you cooked it (or not. Do you)

After that, enjoy.

There is a cooking technique called a salt bake. Usually rese4ved for fish or poultry. Pack rock salt (and a few sprinkles of water to keep it in place) completely around a fish or bird, with seasonings inside the animals cavity. Baked in the oven, it solidifies around it so you have to break it off like clay. It imparts a completely different flavor that isn't usually too salty. It does seal in moisture. I wonder if there is something about that which could be used with molten salt. Maybe a single use clay dish the shape of the steak, filled first with molten salt, place the steak in, and cover it with more molten salt.
